content: Edited to fix typos and slightly improve the formatting.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is kind of a "follow the instructions" game, but it's not so easy, it took me some time to complete it, It's not completely dull since you'll have to handle by yourself bit manipulation and endianness among other things along your implementation. Plus, you'll learn a few things about SHA. It reminded me of the Tensorflow puzzle in a way.
"Apart from this change in initial hash values, the algorithm proceeds exactly the same as the standard implementation."

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's more a "implement the spec" than a real "puzzle" but it's instructive enough to worth a try.
I would have gone further away from the standard implementation to avoid easy copy-pasting. Something like a little-endian hash reading could be added while not breaking any SHA properties.
Anyway, a great puzzle overall, validated!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks hard enough for a Hard puzzle. Also good measures to prevent cheating. Overall, a good puzzle to solve, although lengthy, a lot of fun!

Since it is just changing the initial hash values, you should consider the puzzle as a medium one (it's modular arithmetic and bitwise operations mainly), since you propose the sha-2 pseudocode. Wouldn't be more interesting working directly with the Merkle–Damgård construction algorithm for creating a new kind of SHA, SHA-CG for instance?

Basic rule of cryptography: don't do your own cryptography. Use tested and validated algorithms :)

A stupid mistake anywhere can make the tests fail. I think this is too complex.
A simplified example (SHA-64 ?) would already allow to understand the algorithm.

"A stupid mistake anywhere can make the tests fail" - doesn't that apply to almost every problem on CG? And isn't the point of doing these problems to get better at not making stupid mistakes? Maybe I misunderstood your comment.
If you think it's too complex I can change the difficulty to Hard :)

I think you should.

I agree there is educational value in coding significant algorithms, but there is more, and more intricate, work involved in this than I would expect in a Medium level challenge.

In most of problems, you can infer where is your mistake from the (corner) test case you failed. 
In cryptography you cannot. Either your full code is correct or the test will fail but you cannot compare your result and the expected one.
It's way harder to debug.

Started out following the instructions on the linked website to check it out. The steps are easy to follow.

But I can easily see some of my colleagues struggling and giving up.
There is just no way to throw your current progress on the console and see any meaningful value in it.

I think this would be vastly improved by having to log multiple steps in between.
input
v
log binary form
v
log 512 bit chunks
v
...
v
log final value
